text: wow <@UJKKBAMLL>, storyscript has come a long way in the past few months! great job to you and the team! i'm curious: does the natural language input "stick around" anywhere in the code once it's translated into your scripting language? would be nice to keep it in there as a kind of "dynamic comment"

elements.text: wow

, storyscript has come a long way in the past few months! great job to you and the team! i'm curious: does the natural language input "stick around" anywhere in the code once it's translated into your scripting language? would be nice to keep it in there as a kind of "dynamic comment"

text:
A few thoughts:
• the language translation UX feels right. It makes everything feel more approachable because it knows what you mean. But then again, sometimes it’s more confusing because you don’t even know what you want — you just want to explore. Have you tried using the Emvi experimental UI? It’s super cool, but you feel blind. You have to know what you want to do as soon as you open it.
•  I’m more excited for the whole system you’re building — it sounds like the programming toolkit of every modern-day humans’ dreams. It has got me thinking... The whole “no code” space is going the direction of making something like excel more powerful like programming. But what about the other direction? Maybe you could make a well-crafted typescript library for all of this. You can use the Monaco editor with prettier, eslint and js doc strings. It could be incredibly approachable for the beginner-level JavaScript programmer with auto-complete and popup documentation. They don’t have to worry about deployment or anything. Makes me think of a cross between Mathematica and SmallTalk.
Anyways, interest to see where you go with this!

You have to know what you want to do as soon as you open it.

I’m more excited for the whole system you’re building — it sounds like the programming toolkit of every modern-day humans’ dreams. It has got me thinking... The whole “no code” space is going the direction of making something like excel more powerful like programming. But what about the other direction? Maybe you could make a well-crafted typescript library for all of this. You can use the Monaco editor with prettier, eslint and js doc strings. It could be incredibly approachable for the beginner-level JavaScript programmer with auto-complete and popup documentation. They don’t have to worry about deployment or anything. Makes me think of a cross between Mathematica and SmallTalk.
Anyways, interest to see where you go with this!

text: Another way to think about it is that the NLP is a search capability.  Still, when NLP is used to derive a command, it would be useful to remember what the phrase (or phrases) were.  I mean in practice, I imagine it can take a little hunting to find the right interpretation or the right phrase to get a desired interpretation.

I mean in practice, I imagine it can take a little hunting to find the right interpretation or the right phrase to get a desired interpretation.

text:
<@UG0EL18H3> Thank you! Good to hear from you again as well :slightly_smiling_face: Indeed we have come far.
We believe that you should *“document your business process in the same place it’s automated”* so you leverage rich media and text blocks around the code, we strongly believe this is best for understanding a process since you read code 10x more often than you write it. This can include the original natural language (you can delete it and keep the code only, or keep the language above it). As of now, the NL is not automatically deleted.

elements.text: Thank you! Good to hear from you again as well

text:
<@UT9TWSZB5> Thank you for your kind feedback :thumbsup:
>  because you don’t even know what you want
From my experience, customer interviews, work as a freelancer, work as an leader; I can say with confidence that people know what they want to achieve. We provide other interfaces to “explore” other Stories that people wrote to get inspired. You will never have a blank canvas in Storyscript, it will always guide you and help complete your ideas.

> every modern-day humans’ dreams
:pray: Thank you!!! This is the dream and we are doing our best to build it. Here is my public decade goal: <https://twitter.com/iopeak/status/1242588343096885248>

I have many thoughts and opinions on the “no code” space. I imagine we all do :wink: For me, it boils down to one thing: user experience. I believe anyone can “code” (using this term broadly) given the right tool(s) — It’s no longer a business-person<>programmer w/ CS degree<>computer — It’s just human<>computer. <== that is my dream; however we get there I’m on board. no-code, code, low-code I don’t care. Storyscript is, what I believe, the best of all worlds.

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/iopeak|@iopeak>: Storyscript will be the most used programming language by 2030. There I said it. As Twitter as my witness; this is my goal for this decade.

Storyscript is, what I believe, the best of all worlds.

text: <@UA14TGLTC> Nice catch! I like the way that sounds :slightly_smiling_face: — We have often said “coding is a grammar issue” which I think when you watch  our demo again you’ll see idea is pushed with how the colors, animations, syntax and vocabulary is chosen. We do remember, sorry if the marketing demo is misleading, but we do keep the original NL statement in the document and put the code below it.

text:
I just published the first `alive` release - 0.1-rc1. There's a fully portable windows build available for friction-less installs there, and instructions for other platforms, as well as a getting started guide. You can find everything from the guide:
<https://alive.s-ol.nu/guide.html|https://alive.s-ol.nu/guide.html>

root.text:
I have been working on/with a new interaction model for livecoding for a while, and just put together the first comprehensive summary of the approach:
<https://s-ol.nu/alivecoding>
Feedback (both to text + content) very welcome!

text: Inertia is the most powerful force in the universe, so I think Steve should instead shoot for StoryScript to be used widely and have a loyal fan base. The current tech giants are conspiring to keep JS, Python, etc. firmly entrenched in our workflows, and with the 100 million people learning to code now, the inertia will be even higher.

elements.text: Inertia is the most powerful force in the universe, so I think Steve should instead shoot for StoryScript to be used widely and have a loyal fan base. The current tech giants are conspiring to keep JS, Python, etc. firmly entrenched in our workflows, and with the 100 million people learning to code now, the inertia will be even higher.

text: <@UEQ6M68H0> we fully intend on leveraging the inertia of what we call “tomorrow’s developers”. Our go-to-market is *not* enterprise down, it’s eduction up.

elements.text: we fully intend on leveraging the inertia of what we call “tomorrow’s developers”. Our go-to-market is
not
enterprise down, it’s eduction up.

text: Futhermore, there is no intention to replace Python/JS they have their use case. Storyscript, on the other hand is for business developers that are excluded from the JS/Python/+ communities due to their sheer complex of knowledge required to leverage those languages.

elements.text: Futhermore, there is no intention to replace Python/JS they have their use case. Storyscript, on the other hand is for business developers that are excluded from the JS/Python/+ communities due to their sheer complex of knowledge required to leverage those languages.

text: In our village there is only one person who knows how to fish. They catch fish very well, it feeds some of us, some of go hungry still. Fishing poles keep getting better and better; yet we still only have one fisherman. Instead of building better poles for one fisherman, we built a new pole for the rest of the villagers. It may indeed not be as fast or as flexible, but at least they can catch a fish now.

It may indeed not be as fast or as flexible, but at least they can catch a fish now.
